[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS2_StatePathsProvider.cs] [State Access] [Concurrent State Modification] If State.TransactionFeeFreeAllowancesSymbolList or delegation maps are modified during path calculation, could this cause partial or incorrect path sets? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS2_StatePathsProvider.cs] [Conflict Detection] [Same Address Transfer] If txn.From equals args.To in Transfer, both WritePaths point to same balance - does the conflict detector recognize this as a conflict with other parallel transactions to that address? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS2_StatePathsProvider.cs] [Conflict Detection] [Path Equality Logic] WritePaths.Contains(path) check depends on ScopedStatePath equality - if equality is reference-based not value-based, could identical paths be treated as different? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS2_StatePathsProvider.cs] [Conflict Detection] [ReadPath vs WritePath] Some state is in ReadPaths but not WritePaths - does the conflict detector allow write-write conflicts but prevent read-write conflicts, and is this the correct model? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS2_StatePathsProvider.cs] [Conflict Detection] [Transitive Conflicts] If transaction A writes path X, transaction B writes path Y, and both are related (e.g., allowance and balance), but not explicitly conflicting, could this cause state inconsistency? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS2_StatePathsProvider.cs] [Method Routing] [Method Name Spoofing] If an attacker can craft a transaction with MethodName that matches nameof(Transfer) but different Params structure, could this cause parser errors or incorrect path calculations? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS2_StatePathsProvider.cs] [Method Routing] [Missing Method Handlers] Only Transfer and TransferFrom are handled - if other methods like Approve, Burn, Mint exist but return NonParallelizable, is this a performance issue or security issue? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS2_StatePathsProvider.cs] [Method Routing] [Future Method Addition] If new transfer-like methods are added to the contract but not added to this switch statement, will they incorrectly default to NonParallelizable causing DoS? (Medium)
